title: Quiz 1: FQE July 2016 Paper 1
description: Reproductive Health Final Qualifying Exam - July 2016 (Paper 1) covering short answer and long essay questions converted to interactive formats.

questions.question: A patient presents with a history suggestive of uterine fibroids. Which of the following are recognized SYMPTOMS (patient complaints) of this condition? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Symptoms are what the patient complains of (Menorrhagia, Dysmenorrhea, Pressure symptoms, Dyspareunia). Signs are what the clinician elicits (Palpable mass, Pallor/Anemia, Enlarged uterus).
questions.hint: Distinguish between what the patient feels (symptoms) and what the doctor finds on examination (signs).

questions.question: Which of the following are potential complications associated with uterine fibroids? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Fibroids can cause severe anemia, degeneration (red, hyaline), torsion, infertility, pressure effects (hydronephrosis), and obstetric complications like PPH (not reduced risk).
questions.hint: Think about the mechanical effects of the mass and the impact on bleeding.

questions.question: Match the type of abortion with its clinical description:

pairs.right: PV bleeding, mild pain, cervix CLOSED, viable fetus
Heavy bleeding, severe pain, cervix OPEN, pregnancy cannot be salvaged
Partial expulsion of products, cervix OPEN, tissue remains
Fetus dies but is retained, cervix CLOSED, no initial bleeding
Abortion complicated by infection (fever, foul discharge)

questions.explanation: Threatened: cervix closed, viable. Inevitable: cervix open, loss certain. Incomplete: some products retained. Missed: dead fetus retained. Septic: infection present.
questions.hint: Focus on the state of the cervix and the viability of the fetus.

questions.question: Which of the following are established risk factors (predisposing factors) for Cancer of the Cervix? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Risk factors include HPV infection, early (not late) coitarche, multiple partners, high parity, smoking, immunosuppression, and long-term COC use.
questions.hint: Think about factors that increase exposure to HPV or reduce the body's ability to clear it.

questions.question: Identify the standard components recorded on a Partograph. (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: A partograph tracks FHR, amniotic fluid, moulding, cervical dilation, descent of head, contractions, oxytocin/drugs, maternal vitals, and urine analysis. Maternal height is usually recorded on the admission card, not plotted on the partograph progress chart.
questions.hint: Which of these change over the course of labor and need plotting against time?

questions.question: Arrange the stages of normal labour in the correct chronological order:

items.text: First Stage (Dilation): Onset of true labor to full cervical dilation
Second Stage (Expulsion): Full dilation to delivery of the baby
Third Stage (Placental): Delivery of baby to expulsion of placenta
Fourth Stage (Observation): First 1-2 hours after delivery for monitoring

questions.explanation: Labour progresses from dilation (1st) -> expulsion of fetus (2nd) -> expulsion of placenta (3rd) -> observation period (4th).
questions.hint: Start with the onset of contractions and end with the post-delivery observation.

questions.question: Classify the following complications of Pregnancy Induced Hypertension (PIH) as either Maternal or Fetal:
questions.explanation: Maternal complications affect the mother's organs (Liver/HELLP, Lungs/Edema, Kidneys). Fetal complications affect the baby's growth and oxygenation (IUGR, Asphyxia).
questions.hint: Whose body system is primarily failing in each condition?

questions.question: According to the Focused Antenatal Care (FANC) model, which of the following are the four main pillars/components? (Select 4)

options.text: Early detection and treatment of existing conditions/diseases
Daily fetal movement monitoring at the clinic
Routine admission for rest in third trimester

questions.explanation: The 4 pillars of FANC are: 1. Early detection/treatment of diseases. 2. Prevention (Prophylaxis like IPTp, TT). 3. Birth Preparedness. 4. Health Education.
questions.hint: Think about the broad goals of ANC: Treat, Prevent, Plan, and Educate.

questions.question: A 28-year-old lady delivered 24 hours ago and presents with severe pallor and placenta in situ (Retained Placenta). Arrange the management steps in the correct priority order:

items.text: Resuscitation (ABC, IV fluids, Blood grouping & cross-match)
Manual Removal of Placenta (MROP) under Anesthesia
Administer Oxytocics to control bleeding and ensure contraction

questions.explanation: 1. Resuscitate first (Patient is shocked/pale). 2. Cover with antibiotics (high sepsis risk after 24h). 3. Definitive treatment is removal (MROP) under anesthesia (CCT is unsafe after 24h). 4. Ensure contraction/hemostasis.
questions.hint: Always stabilize the patient before attempting the procedure.

questions.question: Match the infertility investigation with the factor it primarily assesses:
questions.explanation: SFA checks sperm. HSG checks tubes/uterus. Progesterone confirms ovulation. Laparoscopy visualizes pelvis/tubes. Ultrasound checks anatomy.
questions.hint: Connect the test to the specific organ or process being checked.

questions.question: A couple presents with infertility. Which of the following are crucial history points to elicit during evaluation? (Select all that apply)

options.text: History of mumps orchitis or trauma (Male)

questions.explanation: Relevant history includes coital factors, infection history (PID/STIs affect tubes/sperm), medical history (mumps affects testes), and menstrual history (ovulation indicator). Diet is generally less specific unless related to extreme weight.
questions.hint: Focus on factors that directly impact sperm production, ovulation, or transport.
